name: Noreetuh
descriptions: This place was awesome. I was skeptical at first because I didn't want to overload on pork dishes, but I ended up getting the pork katsu for an appetizer and pork belly tortellini as my starter anyways. I don't even know if that was a mistake, because everything was so good. This place had some of the best pasta I've ever had. A 3 course meal for $42 honestly isn't too bad when you consider the quality of each dish and the generous portions in the appetizer. I had a pork katsu to start, which wasn't anything amazing but was cooked perfectly. The main star of the show was the luau leaf pork belly tortellini in a coconut broth, served with shrimp and clams. For dessert, I shared an upside down pineapple cake served with scoops of vanilla, pineapple, and coconut ice cream.

name: The Halal Guys
descriptions: This NYC mainstay has gone global. I've been eating at the Halal Guys food cart from 53rd Street for a while amongst other similar meat over rice options on the streets, but I've never been to the Union Square sit-in location. I wish this location served lamb over rice, but unfortunately they only serve chicken, beef gyro, or a combination of both (they also have falafels, though Mahmoun's Falafel is a better pick for that and is really close by). This is solid Halal Guys food and the decor is nothing special, but let's be honest here, you're here go gorge yourself on cheap street food without actually having to eat on the streets on a cold winter day in Union Square. I will admit, however, that the lettuce and tomatoes they used at this location tasted fresher than what you would usually get elsewhere.

name: Enchiladas
descriptions: If you're craving some Mexican food, this is going to be some of the heaviest, cheesiest messes of beans, meat, and tortilla around. This recipe took less than an hour to make from start to finish including baking time, and was relatively easy to make. While enchiladas aren't exactly something you would want to eat on a daily basis (at least I wouldn't), this recipe definitely hit the spot and satisfied my Mexican food cravings. It reminded me of my time as a Middle School student eating taquitos out of the freezer, only as a sophisticated adult. I know that comparison doesn't really do this recipe justice, but that's still one of the highest praises I can give to a recipe, because I absolutely loved eating bags of frozen taquitos right after school.

name: 21 Shanghai House
descriptions:
Sometimes you need to get a fill of Chinese food, whether it's amazing or not. This was your standard Chinatown fare which is perfectly good and dandy, but nothing truly blew me out of the water. We had drunken chicken, rice cakes, potstickers, soup dumplings, and bamboo shoots with pork. The menus are huge and varied as is the case with most Chinese restaurants, so it's only natural for dishes to be hit or miss.

In our case, the potstickers were too thick and the pork filling wasn't as flavorful as you'd hope. The rice cakes were completely bland and could really have used a kick of soy sauce. As for the rest, the food was great and the atmosphere was busy. That's just how it is when you visit Chinatown for lunch on a weekend, I suppose.

name: Karakatta
descriptions:
I'm going to be completely honest when I say that the only reason that you would stop here as opposed to any other of the amazing ramen shops around NYC is if you were playing board games next door at The Uncommons (which is a fucking awesome place by the way). This place serves a solid bowl of ramen nonetheless, and you'll be attracted like flies to a bright light on a cold winter's day because the whole restaurant is a bright red that's reminiscent of an alarm light in a submarine. Their main takeaway is the Spicy Stamina Ginger Ramen which comes with bamboo shoots, bean sprouts, a boatload of ginger, pork belly, and half an egg. The pork belly was delicious, though I would say that it's kind of hard to mess that up in a ramen! The butter miso is also a solid pick, as the butter gives the miso broth a more hearty flavor to your standard miso ramen fare.

This isn't a terrible place by any means. It's just not a place you would go out of your way to visit when there are so many amazing options available (I'm looking at you, Momosan).

name: Kimchi Fried Rice
descriptions:
Kimchi fried rice is a quick and easy solution to leftovers in the fridge just like any other fried rice recipe. Spam and kimchi is such a good combination of flavors all while being cheap as hell to make. What's even better is when you put cheese on top of the fried rice if you're willing to forego being a traditionalist snob. Don't knock it until you try it, because cheese, spam, and kimchi fried rice is the pinnacle of fusion food done right.

We ate this fried rice with some leftover roasted vegetables (broccoli, mushrooms, onions, zucchini) and some tofu with tomatoes. It can go with pretty much anything, really.

name: Miscelanea
descriptions:
The tortas here are amazing and the bread is freshly baked. Most bodegas that sell sandwiches will toast their bread really hard or use some baguettes that destroy the upper pallet of your mouth, but this bread was warm, fluffy, yet crisp on the outside without being too rough. The chorizo torta was a great brunch option with that fried egg, but the Picadillo torta was even more amazing with the seasoned ground beef, avocado, caramelized onions, and grilled oaxaca cheese. The pickled vegetables and tortilla chips that came with the meal were perfect compliments to the heaviness of the meat.

This place also offered free gum, grasshopper samples, and had their homemade aguas frescas which was a refreshing combination of tamarind, chili, and mango. Overall, this was a great place for brunch, with the only knock being that it was too small of a place and had roughly 4 seats overall.

name: Jeju Noodle Bar
descriptions:
This 2019 Michelin Star restaurant did not disappoint. For appetizers, the chicken wings were hot, crispy, and juicy with the pickled vegetables being a perfect compliment. The Tuna Yuk Hue was a light and refreshing appetizer with cucumber kimchi, roasted marcona almonds, toasted seaweed, and sesame soy sauce drizzled all over the bits of fatty tuna.

The So Ramen was clearly the star of the show, with the raw veal cooking in the broth and adding an extra dimension to the garlicky broth. It was probably the richest ramen broth I've ever had, yet the flavors weren't overpowering at all. The Gochu Ramen was basically what you would expect ramen to taste like with a gochujang broth, and the pork belly was crispy yet tender on the inside.

name: English Breakfast
descriptions:
Apparently English breakfasts were made so that you wouldn't have to eat another meal for the entire day if you were on the road, which explains why this meal is so heavy. This breakfast was fun to make and the combination of baked beans and toast was a pleasant surprise to my Americanized tastebuds. There's nothing that screams amazing about this recipe, but it's good old greasy comfort food in a way that's kind of like your standard American bacon and eggs with hash browns, but with some exotic twists like fried tomatoes and baked beans. I would have loved to try some blood sausage too, but perhaps that will be for another day.

The New Yorkers in us decided to swap bagels for toast because we couldn't be assed to buy a whole loaf of bread if we were going to use roughly two to three slices. But if you're in New York City, why not use a bagel instead? It's damn near impossible to find a shitty bagel in the city.

name: Angkor Cambodian Bistro
descriptions:
Reine's been trying to go to this place three times, and the third time was definitely the charm. Apart from the odd couple two tables apart from us, this place was cozy and welcoming for a Saturday brunch. The Khmer fish cakes were delicious with just the right amount of crispness and spiciness that you would want to compliment the fishy flavors from the patty. The Kuythiew was essentially the Cambodian version of Pad Thai and featured a lot more beansprouts and a type of rice noodle that was rounder and stringer than your usuall Pad Thai noodles. It was reminiscent of the type of noodle you would eat in a high-end instant noodle pack, but I mean that in the most endearing way. It was eggy, salty, sour, sweet, and everything that you would expect in a high quality Pad Thai.

The shrimp and avocado curry was a bit on the pricey side, but I guess that's the price you pay when those damn millennials are ruining Saturday brunches with their avocadoes. Jokes aside, avocado is surprisingly a great complement to red curry, and I'm glad it came out in chunks as opposed to being mashed into the sauce.

name: Parmesan Couscous
descriptions: Couscous is simple to make and it's a great alternative to rice, noodles, or any other version of carbs. This particular version had toasted chopped walnuts, parmesan cheese, spinach, onions, and some leftover pork seasoned with oregano, black pepper, and thyme. I was pleasantly surprised at how this recipe turned out, and was clearly the star of the show when served alongside our rather lackluster ratatouille. Admittedly we did not use any parmesan in the creation of this recipe, but it was not needed whatsoever for a hearty meal. The lemon garlic flavors of this recipe really shone through, while the walnuts provided a satisfying crunch to an otherwise soft meal.

name: Ratatouille
descriptions:
Not sure what the big deal is about ratatouille other than the fact that it's a movie, and that the rat's name is actually Remy. Maybe it's just because we aren't sophisticated enough to cook French cuisine, but these roast vegetables were time consuming and underwhelming. This isn't to say that this recipe is disgusting by any means; infact, tastewise the ratatouille turned out rather good. It's hard to mess up parmesan cheeese with vegetables in an oven. But our first attempt was a soupy mess most likely because our container wasn't wide enough for the vegetables to cook evenly.

...which led us to our second attempt, in which we used the cast iron skillet to fry the vegetables slowly so they would cook evenly. But at that point, we stopped using parmesan cheese because we ran out, and the food was rather bland. I guess you really can't improv on French cooking like you would in other styles, because there really wasn't a lot of seasoning or flavor added to this at all. It's just dependent on some rosemary, thyme, and perfectly cooked ingredients to get the job done, and I guess that's something us amateur chefs don't particularly shine with.

name: Garlic Parmesan Chicken Wings
descriptions:
Garlic parmesan is a tried and true food pairing, especially with chicken wings. This recipe in particular called for the wings to be submerged in a seasoned bath of balsamic vinegar, which gave these wings a pleasant acidity to counteract the natural greasiness of the parmesan. The chili flakes also added an extra dimension of spice that elevated the wings into the 9 star category.

The parmesan crust made the wings extra crispy and everything clumped together into one big delicious mess, and the burnt bits on the tray tasted like gourmet Cheez Its. Overall, this was an amazing use of chicken wings and leftover parmesan cheese. This was paired with the ratatouille in day 2 of our attempt to create a decent version of the recipe, but this clearly outshined the main dish just like the parmesan couscous.

name: Milk Bar
descriptions:
We were inspired to try this place out despite the mediocre Yelp reviews because of the Netflix episode on Chef's Table. Based on what we saw on Chef's Table, we expected to be bombarded with sweets on sweets on sweets that would make the heaviest of sweet tooths cringe at the sugar overload.

Instead, we were intrigued by the strange sweet and savory combinations that were reminiscent of the sugary cereals that both our parents would prevent us from eating, except on rare occasions. The Fruit Loop and cereal milk ice cream was exactly this -- an ice cream with the savory taste of cereal mixed with the sweet, artificial taste of Fruit Loops. The crack pie was delicious and tasted like a block of brown sugar in the most elegant way possible. Would I pay another 7 dollars for such a tiny slice, though? Absolutely not.

name: Chow House
descriptions:
This is a decent Szechuan restaurant around West Village if you don't want to go to Chinatown near Canal Street. I was craving a good mapo tofu, but unfortunately this mapo tofu disappointed. The tofu was way too silky, and the sauce wasn't nearly spicy enough. The consistency was rather goopy and reminiscent of an egg drop soup, and unfortunately there wasn't any ground pork mixed in either. Perhaps my expectations of mapo tofu were skewed because of how I'm usually used to eating the dish.

The spicy cumin lamb was a complete hit, however. It was honestly pretty similar to what you would expect from a Xi'an Famous Foods joint, but had a lot more spice and lamb and did not disappoint. Perhaps the true star of the show was the overly ornate box in which they presented the check to us.

name: Molly's Cupcakes
descriptions:
This was the second time that we've been to Molly Cupcakes. This Food Network Cupcake Wars winner has offered some of the most delicious cupcakes I've ever eaten, and has ignited a passion for cupcakes that I thought I never had. From my experiences, cupcakes were usually dry, the frosting is usually too sweet, and there's not enough balance between the frosting and the rest of the cupcake which hampers the overall experience.

The cupcakes we had at Molly's were actually plays on other superior desserts such as peach cobbler, or creme brulee. During this visit, we had the peanut butter nutella and the tiramisu cupcakes. They might have been a little too sweet, but they were absolutely delicious and tasted like the actual desserts themselves.

name: Taboonette
descriptions: The decor and the plating of this place was really neat. The pans in particular are a great idea, especially when you are a savage eater and tend to get a little messy when eating like me. Simply put your left hand on the pan handle, and use your fork to shovel in the food without any worry of your plate moving around. Unfortunately the sweet potato falafels didn't really taste like sweet potatoes and felt like regular falafel, but the braised lamb shawarma was solid -- especially at the price point and Chipotle-esque aura of this establishment. I would go here for lunch on a regular basis if I wanted a quick bite to eat on a lunch break for sure.

name: Jollibee
descriptions:
I'm glad I finally got the chance to eat true authentic Filipino cuisine.

...or at least something that resembles Filipino food in a way that McDonalds is the representative for American cuisine. We definitely ordered way too much to eat, but it was a pleasure trying some of these foods for the first time; namely, I enjoyed the halohalo, peach mango pie, and chicken adobo rice. The Chickenjoy meal came with 3 pieces of chicken, chicken adobo rice, and a large tub of delicious gravy that I slathered all over my meal. I also had fries, pineapple juice, and some spaghetti with ketchup and hot dogs. While I didn't really like how sweet the spaghetti was, I will admit that the sweetness tasted a bit more intricate than I had originally expected from something that looks and sounds like a struggle meal. I would have loved to try their tuna pie, but perhaps we will save that for another day.

name: Cajun Boil
descriptions: This recipe is a play on cajun boil where the ingredients of a traditional cajun boil are wrapped in aluminum foil and baked in the oven with a blend of spices. The taste was on point, and you really can't go wrong with ingredients like shrimp, andouille sausage, corn, zucchini and potatoes. However, the potatoes were raw and did not cook at the same rate of the rest of the ingredients. If they were sauteed in a pan prior to going in the oven, perhaps they would have been better.

name: Veselka
descriptions:
This is straight up Eastern European comfort food. The veal goulash was simply stewy goodness and the meat melted in my mouth like a thick gravy, which coated the mashed potatoes beautifully as well. The sauerkraut was a great compliment in acidity to cut the heaviness of the meat and potatoes, while the Bigos and beet horseradish salad were similarly delicious but had much stronger flavors in terms of sourness and sweetness.

We ordered an Oboron lager to share because you can't eat this type of food without a nice beer. It did not disappoint!

name: Sergimmo Salumeria
descriptions: This place cuts all the gabbagool ya know? We had due panini with the prosciutto di parma, MUTZADELL, arugula, and a buono fig spread. L'altro panino had grilled chicken, pesto, MUTZADELL, POMODORO TOMATOES, and arugula. This was a solid Italian salumeria with a bunch of imported meats and cheeses hanging all around the restaurant. It was a little dusty, barebones, and what you'd expect from a no-frills Italian-American style establishment, and I love that.

name: Pado
descriptions:
This was a rather new restaurant with some decent selections of sushi at a reasonable price. The orange blossom appetizer was the star of the show: an artful mix of seared salmon with masago, avocado, and soy mustard sauce. As for the other sushi we had, the Manhattan was an interesting mix of smoked salmon, tuna, apple, cucumber and avocado. The hamachi and scallion was the simplest of the rolls and was a pleasant contrast to the heavier soft shell crab spider rolls.

If you check in on Yelp, you get a free scoop of black sesame ice cream. This was a little bit too sweet, but I've got to say that it really tastes similar to the black sesame types of pastries that you would find in a Chinese bakery, and I don't regret trying it out at all (...although it was free).

name: Empanada Mama
descriptions:
This place has a huge menu of specialty empanadas, ranging from your traditional meat empanadas to more novelty items such as the reuben empanada with sauerkraut inside, or the Belgian chocolate and bananas dessert empanada. We had 6 empanadas in total:
- the Viagra (not the pill) was a seafood stew filling with shrimp and crab meat;
- the El Ruben was a shredded beef filling with sauerkraut, caraway seeds, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese;
- the El Toro was a chipotle flavored oxtail braised in red wine;
- the shredded chicken was a slow cooked chicken breast with sofrito sauce;
- the BBQ pulled pork was a slow roasted pork with onions, peppers, cheddar cheese and barbeque sauce;
- the Belgian was a milk chocolate with banana filling.

We couldn't finish all the empanadas because the nachos we ordered were way more filling than we had originally anticipated. It must be because the chips were actually plantain chips instead of tortilla, which is more filling and arguably more tastier. Plantain chips blend in nicely with the rest of the toppings even when they get soggy, which isn't always the case for regular nachos.

name: Bibimbap
descriptions: There are a lot of elements in a bibimbap, but thankfully none of said elements are particularly hard to prepare. Just a couple of blanched vegetables and some seasoned meats should be sufficient, especially when you do it while cooking rice simultaneously. This recipe has a special place in my heart because it's the first recipe that we've tried together (and turned out amazing, obviously). We didn't follow this recipe to a T and left out some of the options noted in this recipe such as the yukhoe (raw beef) and the shiitake mushrooms, but recipes like these always call for some improvisation given how flexible it is. It's basically stir fry assembled in a non-mixed fashion, and simple eats call for simple measures.
